description: Added Jacobi and Legendre polynomial special functions and tests.

messages.text:
Hello golang-dev@googlegroups.com (cc: golang-dev@googlegroups.com),

I'd like you to review this change.

I need some convincing these should be in the standard library at all,
let alone the standard math package.

-rob

It looks like in other languages these functions are
part of a general scientific computing library like
the GNU Scientific Library or SciPy.  I think they are
probably too specialized to be part of the standard
math library, but I'd encourage you to start a collection
of scientific routines on code.google.com or github
that can be goinstalled by people who want to use them
(godoc goinstall).

So far our rule of thumb has been that if it's too
specialized to be part of ANSI C's <math.h> then
it's likely too specialized to be part of package math.

Russ

Thanks for your suggestion. I will make a scigo or something similar on github. I need them for doing spherical harmonics etc. so hopefully others can use them also.

best wishes
kashif

On 2010/12/13 11:22:56, rsc wrote:
> It looks like in other languages these functions are
> part of a general scientific computing library like
> the GNU Scientific Library or SciPy.  I think they are
> probably too specialized to be part of the standard
> math library, but I'd encourage you to start a collection
> of scientific routines on http://code.google.com or github
> that can be goinstalled by people who want to use them
> (godoc goinstall).
> 
> So far our rule of thumb has been that if it's too
> specialized to be part of ANSI C's <math.h> then
> it's likely too specialized to be part of package math.
> 
> Russ
